reason: The module/namespace Nokogiri::HTML4 was introduced to better structure and differentiate between HTML-related classes as of v1.12.0.
The error messages, error locations, and error codes are not part of Nokogiri's public API for semantic version stability. Therefore, they are subject to change without major version change.
Passing options as an explicit hash is deprecated to encourage the use of keyword arguments for better clarity and future compatibility.
The `Nokogiri::XSLT.register` method is not implemented for JRuby, limiting usage to specific Ruby environments. Users are advised to use alternative setups for JRuby compatibility.
The class has been aliased to streamline naming conventions and support more precise version handling.
source: https://nokogiri.org/ (No specific page mentioned in the content; general documentation link provided)

reason: The Nokogiri::HTML4::Builder inherits from Nokogiri::XML::Builder, suggesting users migrate to Nokogiri::XML::Builder for complete documentation coverage.
The apply_to method was introduced as a convenience for combining serialization and transformation steps into a single operation, optimizing code readability and ease of use.

The library transitioned to using an alias for better compatibility and clarity across HTML parsing versions. This change ensures that HTML4 parsing references are explicit and aligned with the newer versioning structure.
Changes were introduced to support enhanced pattern matching and to align with modern Ruby features.
Introduction of HTML5 parsing functionality starting from v1.12.0 and enhancements in v1.14.0
Optimization for faster use of Nokogiri built-in XPath functions in scenarios where it outperforms standard vanilla XPath queries.
Direct usage of the `new` method is not recommended due to better alternatives like `HTML4::DocumentFragment.parse` or `XML::Node#parse`, which offer a more consistent and flexible implementation.
HTML5 functionality has been added since v1.12.0 but is unavailable on JRuby. Additional enhancements were introduced in v1.14.0, such as the ability to retrieve parser quirks mode.
source: Generated from RDoc 6.10.0. Documentation available at Nokogiri's official library.

reason: The alias was introduced to reflect the new naming convention aligning with the version of HTML, ensuring clarity for developers working with HTML4.
The API automatically adapts the XPath query to suit the nature of the document being searched (HTML4, HTML5, XML), ensuring compatibility with various document types.
The class was renamed as an alias for greater consistency in naming conventions.
To incorporate broader support for XML parsing and provide additional functionalities such as improved recovery and correction features.
Passing a Node as the first parameter to CDATA.new is deprecated. The expected first parameter is a Nokogiri::XML::Document to ensure compatibility and avoid errors in future versions.
The class is usually not instantiated directly by the user, and a dedicated parser (Nokogiri::HTML4::SAX::Parser) is provided for better usability.
Updated handling of entity references to comply with improved parsing logic and avoid ambiguity in callbacks.
Introduced as an alias for consistency within the API structure, ensuring backward compatibility and uniformity in naming conventions.
Direct usage of the ParserContext class provides less convenient functionality compared to higher-level methods available in Nokogiri::XML::SAX::Parser.
Recommendation to simplify API usage and encourage developers to use higher-level methods for parsing XML fragments.

deprecated_in: v1.14.0 (specific methods within the API, e.g., `read_io` and `read_memory`)
replaced_by: parse (preferred entry point as noted in the code comments of deprecated methods)
reason: The `read_io` and `read_memory` methods were deprecated to streamline and simplify the API by recommending the use of the more general `parse` method as the preferred entry point for document creation.

The `from_document` and `read_memory` methods are planned for deprecation to consolidate logic into the `new` method, making it the preferred entry point for creating `Nokogiri::XML::RelaxNG` objects and simplifying usage.
The #each method can only iterate through the XML document once. Users must re-parse the document for further iteration.
The PushParser allows for fine-grain control over the XML input, suitable for more precise parsing requirements.
To consolidate file-or-string logic into the `.new` method, making it the preferred entry point for schema creation.

replaced_by: Passing Nokogiri::XML::Document as the second parameter to Text.new
reason: The API is moving away from supporting Nokogiri::XML::Node as the second parameter in favor of requiring Nokogiri::XML::Document to align better with usage patterns and improve clarity.
Some functionality, such as `xmlXPathInit`, was deprecated to streamline the library and align with updates in LibXML.
To improve parsing functionality by allowing developers to specify the exact document type, rather than guessing based on input.
